quizzes.question: What kind of structure does the DOM have?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]The DOM[/h1]

When you open any webpage in a browser, the HTML of the page is loaded and rendered visually on the screen.
To accomplish this, the browser builds the[b] Document Object Model (DOM) [/b]of that page, which is an object oriented model of its logical structure.
The DOM of an HTML document can be represented as a nested set of boxes: [img id="3042" width="100%"]
The DOM represents a document as a [b]tree [/b]structure where HTML elements are interrelated nodes in the tree.
Nodes can have [b]child [/b]nodes. Nodes on the same tree level are called [b]siblings[/b].
jQuery [b]traversing [/b]is the term used to describe the process of moving through the DOM and finding (selecting) HTML elements based on their relation to other elements.
[note]jQuery makes it easy to traverse the DOM and work with HTML elements.[/note]

quizzes.question: Elements that share the same parent are called:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]DOM Traversal[/h1]

For example, consider the HTML represented by the following structure: [img id="3085" width="70%"]
The <html> element is the [b]parent [/b]of <body> and an [b]ancestor[/b] of everything below it.
The <body> element is the [b]parent [/b]of the <h1> and <a> elements.
The <h1> and <a> elements are [b]child [/b]elements of the <body> element and [b]descendants [/b]of <html>.
The <h1> and <a> elements are [b]siblings [/b](they share the same parent).

[h2]Summary[/h2]
An [b]ancestor [/b]is a parent, grandparent, great-grandparent, and so on.
A [b]descendant [/b]is a child, grandchild, great-grandchild, and so on.
[b]Siblings [/b]share the same parent.
[note]Understanding the relationship between the DOM elements is important to be able to traverse the DOM correctly.[/note]
